elements.content: We demonstrate the design of calixarene coordination polymers by using versatile molecular panels comprising binuclear Co(II) clusters and p-carboxylatocalix[4]arenes linked together with 4,4′-bipyridyls. By variation in the length of the 4,4′-bipyridyl, conformational changes in the calixarene molecule have been observed and the solvent-filled channels within the crystalline solid have been adjusted.
elements.clean_text: We demonstrate the design of calixarene coordination polymers by using versatile molecular panels comprising binuclear Co(II) clusters and p-carboxylatocalix[4]arenes linked together with 4,4'-bipyridyls. By variation in the length of the 4,4'-bipyridyl, conformational changes in the calixarene molecule have been observed and the solvent-filled channels within the crystalline solid have been adjusted.

elements.content: We demonstrate the rational design of calixarene coordination polymers via the use of versatile molecular panels comprising binuclear Co(II) clusters and p-carboxylatocalix[4]arene linked through dipyridyls. Variation in linker length causes conformational changes in the calixarene building blocks and influences the presence of solvent-filled channels in the extended structure.
elements.clean_text: We demonstrate the rational design of calixarene coordination polymers via the use of versatile molecular panels comprising binuclear Co(II) clusters and p-carboxylatocalix[4]arene linked through dipyridyls. Variation in linker length causes conformational changes in the calixarene building blocks and influences the presence of solvent-filled channels in the extended structure.

elements.content: The controlled formation of multicomponent nanostructures is a persistent challenge of both supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, primarily because of the need to simultaneously control numerous different intermolecular interactions. Calix[4]arenes have been widely used in these fields of research due to (a) their synthetic accessibility, (b) their possession of cavities that can be used in host–guest chemistry, and (c) facile introduction of structurally useful (or directing) functionality to the general molecular framework. The benzoate moiety has featured prominently in the formation of coordination polymers (CPs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) due to exploitation of commonly observed coordination motifs or secondary building units (SBUs). It is therefore surprising that the p-carboxylato calix[n]arenes (Figure A) have not yet been broadly exploited in the formation of CPs, especially considering that the resulting structures may potentially be tailored so as to present unique host cavities for use in gas sorption and separation (among other things).
elements.clean_text: The controlled formation of multicomponent nanostructures is a persistent challenge of both supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, primarily because of the need to simultaneously control numerous different intermolecular interactions. Calix[4]arenes have been widely used in these fields of research due to (a) their synthetic accessibility, (b) their possession of cavities that can be used in host-guest chemistry, and (c) facile introduction of structurally useful (or directing) functionality to the general molecular framework. The benzoate moiety has featured prominently in the formation of coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to exploitation of commonly observed coordination motifs or secondary building units (SBUs). It is therefore surprising that the p-carboxylato calix[n]arenes (Figure A) have not yet been broadly exploited in the formation of CPs, especially considering that the resulting structures may potentially be tailored so as to present unique host cavities for use in gas sorption and separation (among other things).

elements.content: We recently began to explore the self- and metal-directed assembly of the p-carboxylatocalix[4]arenes (pCO2[4]s), molecules readily accessible in either cone or pinched-cone conformations, depending on lower-rim alteration (Figure A). In the area of noncovalent self-assembly, we utilized the pyridine···carboxylic acid (Py···CO2H) synthon to direct the formation of hydrogen-bonded calixarene dimers through complementary interactions (Figure B); this occurs when lower-rim functionality dictates the presence of a host cavity in the solid state and is observed when lower-rim groups are OH and distal alkoxy for example (1–3, Figure A). For some pCO2[4]s, the hydrogen-bonded dimer is seen to promote the formation of self-assembled nanotubes (Figure C), but this is not a universal phenomenon for all lower-rim derivatives. Upon discovering this, we turned our attention to the formation of metal–organic building blocks based on a commonly observed binuclear transition metal (TM) benzoate motif harvested from the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). These small clusters display a degree of tilt with respect to the orientation of benzoates depending on the ligands present around the metal centers, as shown in Figure D. Lower-rim tetra-O-alkylation of the pCO2[4] framework (e.g., 4, Figure A) orients the upper-rim CO2H groups appropriately, and subsequent cluster formation affords a general assembly motif that displays analogous variance in tilt depending on the solvent employed; ligated methanol produces a small tilt angle with formation of a self-assembled bilayer, while Py promotes greater distortion, forcing nanotube assembly in the solid state (Figure E).
elements.clean_text: We recently began to explore the self- and metal-directed assembly of the p-carboxylatocalix[4]arenes (pCO2[4]s), molecules readily accessible in either cone or pinched-cone conformations, depending on lower-rim alteration (Figure A). In the area of noncovalent self-assembly, we utilized the pyridine⋅⋅⋅carboxylic acid (Py⋅⋅⋅CO2H) synthon to direct the formation of hydrogen-bonded calixarene dimers through complementary interactions (Figure B); this occurs when lower-rim functionality dictates the presence of a host cavity in the solid state and is observed when lower-rim groups are OH and distal alkoxy for example (1-3, Figure A). For some pCO2[4]s, the hydrogen-bonded dimer is seen to promote the formation of self-assembled nanotubes (Figure C), but this is not a universal phenomenon for all lower-rim derivatives. Upon discovering this, we turned our attention to the formation of metal-organic building blocks based on a commonly observed binuclear transition metal (TM) benzoate motif harvested from the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). These small clusters display a degree of tilt with respect to the orientation of benzoates depending on the ligands present around the metal centers, as shown in Figure D. Lower-rim tetra-O-alkylation of the pCO2[4] framework (e.g., 4, Figure A) orients the upper-rim CO2H groups appropriately, and subsequent cluster formation affords a general assembly motif that displays analogous variance in tilt depending on the solvent employed; ligated methanol produces a small tilt angle with formation of a self-assembled bilayer, while Py promotes greater distortion, forcing nanotube assembly in the solid state (Figure E).

elements.content: Here, we demonstrate that calixarene monoacids can be used in the rational design of CPs by combination with a common structural building unit that can be thought of as a molecular panel. In the structures presented, the calixarenes display interesting conformational variability, existing either as all pinched-cone or as mixed cone/pinched-cone conformers; this conformational versatility has no impact on formation of the target molecular panels. This is important with respect to potential downstream host–guest studies within pCO2[4] CPs and is markedly different to the behavior of the pCO2[4]s when forming noncovalent assemblies.
elements.clean_text: Here, we demonstrate that calixarene monoacids can be used in the rational design of CPs by combination with a common structural building unit that can be thought of as a molecular panel. In the structures presented, the calixarenes display interesting conformational variability, existing either as all pinched-cone or as mixed cone/pinched-cone conformers; this conformational versatility has no impact on formation of the target molecular panels. This is important with respect to potential downstream host-guest studies within pCO2[4] CPs and is markedly different to the behavior of the pCO2[4]s when forming noncovalent assemblies.

elements.content: (A) Schematic of selected pCO2[4]s. (B) H-bonded pCO2[4] dimer formed with Py template. (C) Noncovalent pCO2[4] nanotube. (D) Common binuclear cluster motif with general formula [TM2(benzoate)4(Py)2]. (E) Binuclear TM pCO2[4] cluster that assembles into metal–organic nanotubes due to tilt in the constituent building block. Figures not to scale and H atoms omitted for clarity in (B–E).
elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Schematic of selected pCO2[4]s. (B) H-bonded pCO2[4] dimer formed with Py template. (C) Noncovalent pCO2[4] nanotube. (D) Common binuclear cluster motif with general formula [TM2(benzoate)4(Py)2]. (E) Binuclear TM pCO2[4] cluster that assembles into metal-organic nanotubes due to tilt in the constituent building block. Figures not to scale and H atoms omitted for clarity in (B-E).

elements.content: As a starting point toward rational CP design, we searched the CSD for common, planar binuclear metal clusters (formed with multiple TMs) with a view to constructing a versatile molecular panel. The general [TM2(benzoate)4(Py)4] structure shown in Figure can be formed with either Co, Mn, and Cd under various conditions and thus presented itself as a strong candidate for panel synthesis with calixarene monoacids 5 and 6 (Figure A). Selection of this target motif was also driven by previously reported CP formation with various bipyridine linkers that can readily be changed without alteration to the molecular panel. From this viewpoint, the motif could thus be used to construct discrete or polymeric structures from a calixarene monoacid.
elements.clean_text: As a starting point toward rational CP design, we searched the CSD for common, planar binuclear metal clusters (formed with multiple TMs) with a view to constructing a versatile molecular panel. The general [TM2(benzoate)4(Py)4] structure shown in Figure  can be formed with either Co, Mn, and Cd under various conditions and thus presented itself as a strong candidate for panel synthesis with calixarene monoacids 5 and 6 (Figure A). Selection of this target motif was also driven by previously reported CP formation with various bipyridine linkers that can readily be changed without alteration to the molecular panel. From this viewpoint, the motif could thus be used to construct discrete or polymeric structures from a calixarene monoacid.

elements.content: Target [TM2(benzoate)4(Py)4] molecular panel. H atoms omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Target [TM2(benzoate)4(Py)4] molecular panel. H atoms omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Ambient reactions were carried out between DMF solutions containing a calixarene monoacid (5, Figure A), Co(II) nitrate, and methanolic solutions of 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy), 4,4′-bipyridylethane (bpa), or 4,4′-bipyridylethylene (bpe) to afford [Co2(5)4(bipy)2]·6DMF (7), [Co2(5)4(bpa)2]·8DMF (8), and [Co2(5)4(bpe)2]·8DMF (9), respectively. Structure analysis of 7 reveals formation of the target molecular panel (Figure A), with the two pCO2[4]s residing on either side of the near-planar motif. The panel conforms to a parallelogram and has dimensions of 1.8 × 1.0 nm (measured between centroids generated from pCO2[4] lower-rim oxygens), representing a very large building unit/panel. Symmetry expansion shows that the panels are linked in the desired fashion via two bipys on either side to afford a CP chain, as shown in Figure B. Tetra-O-alkylation of the calixarene lower-rim during synthesis generally precludes guest inclusion in the resulting pCO2[4]. This is observed in the present structure, with all calixarenes existing as pinched-cone conformers, as shown in Figure A. Co-crystallized DMF molecules occupy space around the panel, residing in interstitial regions between neighboring CP chains.
elements.clean_text: Ambient reactions were carried out between DMF solutions containing a calixarene monoacid (5, Figure A), Co(II) nitrate, and methanolic solutions of 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy), 4,4'-bipyridylethane (bpa), or 4,4'-bipyridylethylene (bpe) to afford [Co2(5)4(bipy)2]⋅6DMF (7), [Co2(5)4(bpa)2]⋅8DMF (8), and [Co2(5)4(bpe)2]⋅8DMF (9), respectively. Structure analysis of 7 reveals formation of the target molecular panel (Figure A), with the two pCO2[4]s residing on either side of the near-planar motif. The panel conforms to a parallelogram and has dimensions of 1.8 × 1.0 nm (measured between centroids generated from pCO2[4] lower-rim oxygens), representing a very large building unit/panel. Symmetry expansion shows that the panels are linked in the desired fashion via two bipys on either side to afford a CP chain, as shown in Figure B. Tetra-O-alkylation of the calixarene lower-rim during synthesis generally precludes guest inclusion in the resulting pCO2[4]. This is observed in the present structure, with all calixarenes existing as pinched-cone conformers, as shown in Figure A. Co-crystallized DMF molecules occupy space around the panel, residing in interstitial regions between neighboring CP chains.

elements.content: (A) Near orthogonal views of the large [TM2(pCO2[4] monoacid)4] molecular panel found in [Co2(5)4(bipy)2]·6DMF (7), with lower-rim pCO2[4] alkyl chains omitted for clarity. (B) The CP chain in the extended structure of 7. Figures not to scale and cocrystallized DMF omitted for clarity in both cases.
elements.clean_text: 3  (A) Near orthogonal views of the large [TM2(pCO2[4] monoacid)4] molecular panel found in [Co2(5)4(bipy)2]⋅6DMF (7), with lower-rim pCO2[4] alkyl chains omitted for clarity. (B) The CP chain in the extended structure of 7. Figures not to scale and cocrystallized DMF omitted for clarity in both cases.

elements.content: Structural analysis of 8 and 9 reveals essentially isostructural coordination chemistry to that found in 7 with respect to CP formation (i.e., panels linked via the 4,4′-bipyridyl derivatives, Figure ), but one notable difference in the molecular panels is evident. In both 8 and 9, the panel motif contains two crystallographically unique pCO2[4]s that adopt cone rather than pinched-cone conformations. This occurs with concomitant inclusion of a cocrystallized DMF molecule in each calixarene cavity; typical CH··· π interactions are observed between DMF methyl groups and the aromatic rings of the calixarene framework. This is a particularly interesting feature when one considers the host–guest behavior of p-tert-butylcalix[4]arene toward gases such as CO2 and the potential that these molecules may hold with respect to CP/MOF construction. Further analysis of the bpe linked CP (9) showed that the alkenes are positioned such that it may be possible to perform a single-crystal-to-single-crystal [2 + 2] photodimerization in line with Schmidt’s topochemical criteria for photochemical cycloaddition (alkenes ∼3.7 Å apart). Subsequent experiments unfortunately revealed that the structure remained unchanged following long exposure to UV light, indicating that this orientation was not in fact optimal for the reaction to take place.
elements.clean_text: Structural analysis of 8 and 9 reveals essentially isostructural coordination chemistry to that found in 7 with respect to CP formation (i.e., panels linked via the 4,4'-bipyridyl derivatives, Figure ), but one notable difference in the molecular panels is evident. In both 8 and 9, the panel motif contains two crystallographically unique pCO2[4]s that adopt cone rather than pinched-cone conformations. This occurs with concomitant inclusion of a cocrystallized DMF molecule in each calixarene cavity; typical CH⋅⋅⋅ π interactions are observed between DMF methyl groups and the aromatic rings of the calixarene framework. This is a particularly interesting feature when one considers the host-guest behavior of p-tert-butylcalix[4]arene toward gases such as CO2  and the potential that these molecules may hold with respect to CP/MOF construction. Further analysis of the bpe linked CP (9) showed that the alkenes are positioned such that it may be possible to perform a single-crystal-to-single-crystal [2 + 2] photodimerization in line with Schmidt's topochemical criteria for photochemical cycloaddition (alkenes ~3.7 Å apart). Subsequent experiments unfortunately revealed that the structure remained unchanged following long exposure to UV light, indicating that this orientation was not in fact optimal for the reaction to take place.

elements.content: Sections of the extended single crystal structures of (A) [Co2(5)4(bpa)2]·8DMF (8) and (B) [Co2(5)4(bpe)2]·8DMF (9). DMF molecules occupying cone conformer pCO2[4]s are shown in the blue space filling representation. Other DMF molecules and H atoms (except those of ethane and ethylene groups of bpa and bpe, respectively) are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  Sections of the extended single crystal structures of (A) [Co2(5)4(bpa)2]⋅8DMF (8) and (B) [Co2(5)4(bpe)2]⋅8DMF (9). DMF molecules occupying cone conformer pCO2[4]s are shown in the blue space filling representation. Other DMF molecules and H atoms (except those of ethane and ethylene groups of bpa and bpe, respectively) are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Another notable difference observed in the crystal packing of 7, compared to both 8 and 9, is the distance between the centroids of molecular panels between two neighboring CPs. In 7, this distance is found to be 1.6 nm, which is greater by 0.3 nm to the analogous distances found in both 8 and 9 (Figure D). The alignment of neighboring CP chains is necessarily dictated by the length of the linker between the molecular panels; this has a concomitant effect on the potential for interdigitation between neighboring CP chains. In 7, the bipy linker (1.1 nm) is shorter than the linker in 8 (bpa) and 9 (bpe), both being 1.4 nm long. This shorter linker precludes efficient packing and causes the CPs to assemble with the significantly greater interchain distance. In contrast, the linkers in both 8 and 9 are long enough to facilitate interdigitation of calixarenes from panels of neighboring CPs (Figure D). The less efficient packing of CPs in 7 results in the formation of solvent-filled channels, as shown in Figure A. The self-assembly of CPs with slightly longer linkers [bpa (Figure B) and bpe (Figure C)] results in a disruption of the packing observed in 7, and rather than forming solvent channels in the solid state, the CPs align to form solvent pockets. This is an interesting feature, and it provides insight into the method of controlling both assembly and the design of porous materials. For example, structures containing panels of bulky, wedge-shaped organic building blocks (e.g., calixarenes) may promote the formation of solvent-filled pockets/channels, the exact nature of which may depend on the degree of interdigitation.
elements.clean_text: Another notable difference observed in the crystal packing of 7, compared to both 8 and 9, is the distance between the centroids of molecular panels between two neighboring CPs. In 7, this distance is found to be 1.6 nm, which is greater by 0.3 nm to the analogous distances found in both 8 and 9 (Figure D). The alignment of neighboring CP chains is necessarily dictated by the length of the linker between the molecular panels; this has a concomitant effect on the potential for interdigitation between neighboring CP chains. In 7, the bipy linker (1.1 nm) is shorter than the linker in 8 (bpa) and 9 (bpe), both being 1.4 nm long. This shorter linker precludes efficient packing and causes the CPs to assemble with the significantly greater interchain distance. In contrast, the linkers in both 8 and 9 are long enough to facilitate interdigitation of calixarenes from panels of neighboring CPs (Figure D). The less efficient packing of CPs in 7 results in the formation of solvent-filled channels, as shown in Figure A. The self-assembly of CPs with slightly longer linkers [bpa (Figure B) and bpe (Figure C)] results in a disruption of the packing observed in 7, and rather than forming solvent channels in the solid state, the CPs align to form solvent pockets. This is an interesting feature, and it provides insight into the method of controlling both assembly and the design of porous materials. For example, structures containing panels of bulky, wedge-shaped organic building blocks (e.g., calixarenes) may promote the formation of solvent-filled pockets/channels, the exact nature of which may depend on the degree of interdigitation.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have shown that a rational approach can be taken toward the construction of versatile CPs from nanoscale panels, comprising pCO2[4]s. Careful choice of coordination motif and pCO2[4] has afforded a series of CPs with various 4,4′-bipyridyl linkers, and changes in the calixarene conformation have been observed with concomitant guest inclusion. Furthermore, by varying the length of the 4,4′-bipyridyl linker, the presence of solvent-filled channels or pockets can be subsequently adjusted. These principles can be extended to the design of other new assemblies with known properties (e.g., magnetism) that utilize molecular panels as constituent building blocks. These avenues of investigation are underway, and the results will be reported in due course.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have shown that a rational approach can be taken toward the construction of versatile CPs from nanoscale panels, comprising pCO2[4]s. Careful choice of coordination motif and pCO2[4] has afforded a series of CPs with various 4,4'-bipyridyl linkers, and changes in the calixarene conformation have been observed with concomitant guest inclusion. Furthermore, by varying the length of the 4,4'-bipyridyl linker, the presence of solvent-filled channels or pockets can be subsequently adjusted. These principles can be extended to the design of other new assemblies with known properties (e.g., magnetism) that utilize molecular panels as constituent building blocks. These avenues of investigation are underway, and the results will be reported in due course.

elements.content: Ball and stick and vdW representation of the crystal packing along the linker axis showing solvent channels and pockets: (A) [Co2(5)4(bipy)2]·6DMF (7), (B) [Co2(5)4(bpa)2]·8DMF (8), and (C) [Co2(5)4(bpe)2]·8DMF (9), and (D) distances between neighboring CPs with red line indicating the linker and blue parallelogram, indicating the molecular panel for 7, 8, and 9. Hydrogen atoms, DMF molecules, and 4,4′-bipyridyl linkers omitted for clarity.

Hydrogen atoms, DMF molecules, and 4,4'-bipyridyl linkers omitted for clarity.

metadata.title:
Molecular Paneling in the Rational Design of Calixarene
Coordination Polymers
